description: Erection of temporary marquee for Christmas Event
decision_conditions: As part of the Council's Local List of Validation (3d) requirements this application needs to be accompanied by a supporting 'Existing and Proposed Street Scenes'.  Please provide the street scenes.  A copy of the Royal Borough of Kingston's information requirements and guidance on what the street scene should contain are available on our website at www.kingston.gov.uk/planning.

Please provide  copies of existing and proposed elevations (from the other side) at a recognised scale of 1:50 or 1:100, providing a scale bar, showing outline of entire property not just part and showing dimensions of proposed work. If the proposed works are not visible from the other side, please provide a shaded outline of the house.

The fee required for your planning application is £ 103.00.  If payment is by cheque please make payable to Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames or via the Contact Centre on 0208 547 5002. You may also pay online via the RBK website www.kingston.gov.ukIf the application is an alternative proposal being submitted on the same site by thesame applicant on the same day, where this application is of lesser cost then the fee is50%

The marquee hereby permitted shall only be erected during the following dates*, outside of these dates the marquee and all associated equipment shall be removed and the land restored to its former condition by 31 January 2020.*05th November 2019 to 31st December 2019 Reason: To ensure that the setting of the nearby listed building and the character and appearance of this part of the Conservation Area are not unduly and permanently compromised in accordance with Policies DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) and DM12 (Development in Conservation Areas and Affecting Heritage Assets) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012, and in order that the Local Planning Authority may review the position at the end of that period.

The hereby approved temporary use of the site as a 'Christmas Craft Fair'  shall only operate during the following dates*, and outside these dates the use shall cease. *05th November 2013 to 24th December 2019 Reason: In the interest of visual and neighbouring amenity in accordance with Policies DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) and DM12 (Development in Conservation Areas and Affecting Heritage Assets) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012, and in order that the Local Planning Authority may review the position at the end of that period.

The marquee hereby approved shall not be open to the public for the purposes hereby permitted before 0930am or after 2000pm Mondays to Saturdays, and before 1100 am or after 1800 pm on Sundays and Bank Holidays.Reason: To safeguard the amenities of the occupiers of the neighbouring properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012

All works shall be undertaken strictly in accordance with the documents / plans hereby approved, unless otherwise agreed in writing by the Local Planning Authority.Reason: In the interests of visual amenities and so that the Local Planning Authority shall be satisfied as to the details of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy adopted April 2012.

The development hereby approved shall be carried out strictly in accordance with the approved document titled BS5837:2012 Survey and Report (dated October 2019) and shall be maintained throughout the entire period of the development.Reason: In order to protect the health of the trees at the site in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The development approved by this planning permission will be liable to pay the Mayor of London's Community Infrastructure Levy (MCIL).  Payment will be due once the owner/developer serves a development Commencement Notice on the Council, and a payment Demand Notice has been received by the owner.  Failure to submit a Commencement Notice will incur a surcharge of 20% of the chargeable amount or £2,500, whichever is the lower amount.   When you have discharged all pre-commencement conditions the Council will issue a Liability Notice to the owner setting out the MCIL calculation.  Accompanying the Liability Notice will be a  blank Commencement Notice and if necessary a blank Assumption of Liability form, both of which need to be completed and returned to the Council prior to development commencing. In dealing with the application the Council has implemented the requirement in the National Planning Policy Framework to work with the applicant in a positive and proactive way. We have made available detailed advice in the form of our statutory policies in the Core Strategy, Supplementary Planning Documents, Planning Briefs and other informal written guidance, as well as offering a full pre-application advice service, in order to ensure that the applicant has been given every opportunity to submit an application which is likely to be considered favourably. However the amendments required to make the application acceptable are substantial and would materially change the development proposal.

Inspection:Site inspection carried out as a desktop exercise due to COVID19 lockdown. Photos provided by the applicant as supporting material to application.Assessment:Trees to the rear of the property and not having much impact on public amenity being not very visible from the street. The works to the Acacia which is clearly in decline having been topped in the past, are acceptable to reduce overhang and the Birch is not worthy of a TPO. The Council's position should therefore be one of no objections.Recommendation:No objections.

Inspection:Site inspection carried out as a desktop exercise due to COVID19 lockdown. Photos provided by the applicant as supporting material to application.Assessment:Minor works to reduce root nodules lifting adjacent hard surfacing following expert advice.Recommendation:Approve.

Inspection:Site inspection carried out as a desktop exercise due to COVID19 lockdown. Photos provided by the applicant as supporting material to application.Assessment:Minor repeat works carried out to ensure adequate light levels to the property and retain trees at appropriate size.Recommendation:Approve.

Inspection:Site inspection carried out as a desktop exercise due to COVID19 lockdown. Photos provided by the applicant as supporting material to application.Assessment:The tree in question is a large mature oak and the only mature tree cover on the property itself. It constitutes a part of the green corridor on the Upper Brighton Road and contributes significantly to the appearance of the conservation area due to its high visibility to the public and its subsequent public amenity value. It has been maintained over the years with a greater emphasis on reducing shade within the property and as such now has a heavier canopy over the road. The owner complains that the tree has been shedding branches and that these were not only deadwood but also live limbs and that this shedding is fairly regular and risks causing damage to the house itself and danger to its inhabitants, however no evidence of limb loss can be seen or has been provided and neither has a technical report been provided by an Arborist substantiating that there is anything wrong with the tree. There is also no evidence of existing property damage and permission cannot be granted for the removal of such a tree on the basis of possibility. It is plausible that the tree may have shed a higher number of small branches due to the two particularly long dry summers we have experienced. If this is the case then carrying out reduction works should help to mitigate this issue and reduce the demand that a larger crown exerts upon the tree whilst also reducing wind loading and likelihood of damage or limb loss due to storm events. It will also give an opportunity to reshape the tree appropriately and remove any deadwood or limbs that are obviously prone to failure.Recommendation:Refuse & grant lesser works as follows:T.35 Oak - Remove lowest primary limb extending over A243 (Upper Brighton Road) back to branch collar at main trunk. Crown lift secondary growth of remaining canopy to 2m above ridge line of house and match throughout. Reduce upper crown by 3m, laterally reduce crown over road to south by 2-3m and laterally reduce crown over property to North by 2m, reshaping to give natural evenly balanced crown shape with all cuts made to suitable growth points and all deadwood and problematic secondary growth prone to failure removed.

Inspection:Site inspection carried out as a desktop exercise due to COVID19 lockdown. Photos provided by the applicant as supporting material to application.Assessment:The Lime at 28 Gibbon Road was last pollarded in 2014-15 around the same time as planning permission was granted to build a new dwelling on the site. These works would not have caused any issues to the tree and the developer worked hard to ensure that the tree was not damaged during the course of development along with specialist foundations on the front elevation. Unfortunately during the early days of the development when it was still going through the planning process, a utility company for gas and electrics entered the site and carried out works to provide the site with services. During the process they dug down into the root protection area of the tree fairly close to the trunk and severed some fairly major roots in order to lay their new service lines. As the tree is subject to a TPO the Council would normally have taken immediate legal action over this, but unfortunately utility companies are exempt from having to apply for permission in law, they are termed a 'statutory body' and the Council cannot take action against them for harming a protected tree.So moving on, the only thing the Council could do was permit works to repollard and wait and hope that the tree would recover. Early signs were good and there was a profusion of initial growth. Unfortunately though this never happened in the upper crown, only in the lower crown and trunk in the form of epicormic growth. This is very likely due to entrenchment as the tree is attempting to survive by shutting down support to the upper limbs and promoting growth to the lower limbs and trunk. It is very unlikely though that the tree will ever substantially recover at this point and the upper crown will most likely die off completely and then rot away opening the main trunk to cavities and central decay. This was not known until I saw the latest photos of the tree submitted in support of the current application.Although this application was originally for repollarding the tree, in the light of the above, I have spoken with the owners about removal including of the stump and planting a replacement tree in fresh top soil. They have agreed to this and as such my recommendation is to permit felling via this application with a condition to plant a replacement.Recommendation:Approve Fell with condition for replacement tree; Prunus sargentii.
